Scenario: If I’m worried about treatment before it’s started...
Options:
* Practice relaxation techniques (mindfulness, deep breathing)​ 
* Seek pre-treatment counselling or fertility coaching​ 
* Talk openly with your partner or support group about fears​ 
* Focus on controllable factors (sleep, diet, information)

Scenario: If I feel a stigma around IVF treatment...
Original Title: Stigma around infertility and assisted reproduction​
Options:
* Connect with online/peer support groups​ 
* Educate close friends/family about infertility to reduce stigma​ 
* Practice self-compassion — infertility is a medical condition, not a personal failure.

Scenario: If I feel pressure from my family or friends when we talk about treatment...
Original Title: Social Pressure from Family or Community​
Options:
* Set healthy boundaries and limit fertility-related discussions​ 
* Communicate clearly with family about your needs​ 
* Engage a counsellor to practice responses to pressure situations

Scenario: If I feel worried about the cost of treatment...
Options:
* Save in advance or explore clinic financing options​ 
* Research the true cost of medications and procedures​ 
* Budget for multiple cycles realistically to reduce future pressure.

* Attend pre-IVF education sessions​ 
* Request detailed treatment timelines and expectations​ 
* Prepare mentally and physically — rest, nutrition, planning time off.

Scenario: If I’m worried about the treatment not working...
Options:
* Ask your clinic for realistic success rates based on age and health​ 
* Set emotional “check-in points” between decisions​ 
* Accept that uncertainty is part of the process — plan flexible next steps

Scenario: If I feel physically unwell during treatment...
Options:
* Take time off work  
* Preparing mentally  
* Practising self-care

Scenario: If I’m worried about how my body will react to the treatment...
Original Title: Not knowing how your body will react
Options:
* Research the effects of treatment, ​ 
* know possible side effects, ​ 
* prepare the body to be in an optimal condition, ​ 
* take treatment one step at a time

Scenario: If my work or daily activities are affected during treatment...
Original Title: Negative effect of treatment on work or daily activities
Options:
* Plan in advance 
* Take time off 
* Arrange work around treatment  
* Seek support from the employer  
* Communicate with work colleagues

Scenario: If I feel physically unwell during treatment...
Options:
* Counselling  
* Seeking support from family, friends, partner and support group  
* Remain positive 
* Hopeful and optimistic about treatment success  
* Learn from others  
* Take one thing at a time

Scenario: If treatment starts to affect on my relationship...
Options:
* Open, honest and frequent communication with partner  
* Plan to spend time with partner  
* Engage in fun activities  
* Support and understanding for each other in counselling

Scenario: If I’m worried that my cycle won’t be successful...
Original Title: Coping with the possibility that the cycle is unsuccessful
Options:
* Counselling  
* Seeking support from family, friends, partner and support group  
* Remain positive 
* Hopeful and optimistic about treatment success  
* Being realistic about treatment success from the start  
* Get advice from individuals who have previous experience
